loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Being a mother, 54-year-old Letecia T. is concerned about the lives her married children, her husband and their 22-year-old child who lives with and is dependent on her. Most of her children have unstable sources of income and are still under the umbrella of poverty.

To improve her living conditions, she recently joined a KIVA field partner in the Philippines, ASHI, to be able to access a loan which will enable her to start her business. Through this loan she plans to start up her own hog (pig raising) business. The profits she will earn from selling the hogs after four months of fattening would augment her husband’s income as a farmer. As the business grows, she would be able to support more of her children and grandchildren’s needs.  By then, her role being a mother would be completed.

loans.use: To buy piglets for fattening and selling. Also, some portion will be used to purchase materials for building a pig pen.

The family lives along the highway at Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela.

Rebecca operates a tricycle transportation business and is also engaged in a retailing business. Her net income is PHP 250 daily from her transport business and PHP 500 a week from her retailing business.

Rebecca wants to request a loan of PHP 15,000 from Kiva lenders to purchase additional grocery items to sell in her retail store and also for the maintenance of their motorcycle in order to have a productive and fruitful business income.

loans.name: Lorence

texts.en: Lorence L., 46, has been providing her neighbors, and even friends abroad, with her home-made cured fish for almost three years now. She lives in Zabarte, Caloocan City. Her 53 year old husband, Ireneo, is an auto electrician. Their only child is still in grade school. Lorence carefully debones bangus (milkfish - the country’s national fish) and cures them for longer shelf life. Her finished products appeal to a lot to her customers so that she always finds herself working overtime to meet their demands. Her cured bangus now reaches her friends overseas at an additional fee for handling. In addition, she also delivers fresh pork meat to her neighbors. Lorence is thankful to the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for providing her with loans which she has used to buy fresh bangus in bulk. She now earns at least P9,000 a month but her earnings sometimes vary depending on the supply of fresh meat and fish and the demand for finished products. Lorence uses her profits to support the daily needs of her family, especially her child’s education. She applied for a new loan of P17,000 from CCT Credit Cooperative. She wishes to come up with an appealing packaging for her cured fish for better marketability. She also wishes that her products qualify for the export standards. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her food preparation business

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda manages a livestock business where she raises ducks and sells them for PHP 120 per kilo. Aside from raising ducks, she also sells vegetables in their village and in the public market of Cauayan City.

Belinda decided to request a loan of PHP 4,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital that she needs to improve her two businesses. She plans to use the loan to make a shelter for her ducks and to provide for their growth. She continuously works hard for the sake of her family to meet their needs.

Belinda is 36 years old and is married to Walter, a farmer. They have four children: Algery, 16 years old, in fourth-year high school; Julius, 14 years old, in third-year high school; Zyra, 5 years old, in preschool; and Amir, 1 year old. They live at Nungnungan, Cauayan City, a rural area. Their house is located along the highway.

loans.use: To build a shelter for her ducks

loans.name: Roth

texts.en:
Roth T., 48, is a widow with four children and resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, with her children.

T. is engaged in the business of selling a few types of meatballs made from fish and beef, earning an income of approximately US$2 per day. This is the primary source of income for her family.

The family is also assisted by three of her children who are currently employed at a local garment factory. They are able to earn a reasonable income to make a living and to help cover their mother’s household expenses.

The members of T.’s family are seeking to improve their standard of living and to expand their current business. Therefore, T. is asking for a loan of $200 to expand her business by selling food (rice and meat) for breakfast. By doing so, T. hopes that her business will go well so that she is able to generate extra income for future household use.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores works hard at her trade, selling rice, and hopes to increase her income by buying more sacks of rice to sell. She is committed to expand her business, and has applied for this loan to make that expansion possible.

Dolores is 58 years old and lives in the town of Palattao in Naguilian, Isabela. She is happily married to Benito, a farmer. They have three children, two of whom are married. Dolores aims to improve her way of life by working hard at her trade.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice to sell to her customers

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida M. lives in the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She makes a living by cooking and selling food, particularly snacks and delicacies popular in her community. She has been in this business for more than four years, and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from her work.

In June 2009, Zenaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and her business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from HSPFI, and has applied for a new loan to buy the ingredients she needs to make new items to cook and sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to continue to expand and improve her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy ingredients needed to made food items she sells to her customers

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily Rebeca makes a living selling beads and jewelry in an open market in her community, and has applied for this loan to buy necklaces to sell to her customers. She is 32 years old, married to a businessman and has five children, all of whom are in school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she plans to open a jewelry shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy necklaces to sell to her customers

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M. (shown here with her young students) is 43 years old and lives and works in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. Her husband Danilo makes a living as a driver, and they have two children.

Marites runs a community pre-school. She also established and manages a canteen located inside the school. On slow days at school, she supplements her income by selling cosmetics and apparel. With all these businesses, she makes close to PHP7,000 a month. 

Marites joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006.  Her profits, when added to loans provided by the cooperative, have helped her improve her school. She has repaid several loans, and has now applied for a new one for PHP26,000. She will use this loan to buy food to sell at her canteen.

Marites hopes to expand her school and improve its reputation so that it is known not just in her community, but in neighboring ones as well.    

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is Christian response to poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to buy supplies for the school canteen

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda G. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 26 years old. Rosalinda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a business in the retail sector operating a variety store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling variety of products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and business activities. Rosalinda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosalinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell from her variety store

loans.name: Yvonne

texts.en:
Yvonne is engaged in making home made embutido (Embutido is a Filipino style of meatloaf wrapped in an aluminum foil) for three years and sells them in her village. Due to a limited budget to produce more embutido, she wants to borrow a loan from the KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP5,000 to have additional capital to buy the necessary ingredients. She hopes to expand her business and earn more income to sustain the needs of her family. Through this loan, she believes that her business will grow and become more profitable. She hopes that her loan request will be granted. 

Yvonne is 47 years old and married to Victor, a bus driver. The couple is blessed with three children who are all college graduates.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy ingriedients to produce "embutido"

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 47 years old and works as a dress maker in the village of Magsaysay Saguday, Quirino.  She is married to Rodolfo, a rice farmer.  The couple were blessed with three children: Vanesa, 26 years old, a college graduate; Aaron John, 17 years old, a college student and the youngest, Jocel Marie, 15 years old, a 4th year high school student.

Lolita would like to improve her dress making business so that she could continue to support the schooling of her children. She would like to ask for financial assistance from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP12000. Lolita would be glad if her request would be approved. She also prays that through the loan, her business will become profitable.

loans.use: Additional capital to improve her dress making business

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Favour is 29 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a civil servant. She sells food spices like tomato paste, garlic, curry, etc. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profit during this season. She hopes to own a grocery stall in the future. She hopes for a loan of N120,000 to purchase more food spices to sell. She expresses her gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food spices to sell

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
Ethel R. is from the village of Bugwac, Catohugan Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 28 years old. Ethel is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Ethel owns & operates a variety store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Ethel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ethel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ethel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ethel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Zama

texts.en:
Zama F. is currently in the business of selling bread and green vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase maize flour and beans to sell.  Zama is 28 years old and is married to a peasant. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence sells foodstuffs and local gin to make a living within her community in Lagos state, Nigeria. Her husband sells drinks and local gin. She is 40 years old and has five children. She is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes to expand her business. She hopes for a loan of N140,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and local gin to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Ronel

To make a living, Ronel runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ronel has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ronel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Ronel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & for working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ronel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 47 years old and married to Mario, a farmer. They have two children: Mario Jeoffrey, 24 years old, who is a Criminology graduate and Lei Angela, 20 years old, who is a fourth year college student. Lucia and her family live in the village of Palattao, Naguilian, Isabela. She hopes to provide for educational needs of her youngest through her income from the business.  

Lucia is engaged in selling different commodities such as fruits, vegetables, meat, chicken, fish and so on. She displays her products on their terrace. She has been managing this business for 16 years and is hoping for continuous improvement.  For this reason, she requests a loan of PHP 5,000 that she will use to purchase more commodities for her retail business.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en: At the age of 50, Tessie B. still dreams of having a shelter that will secure her and her husband against any harm brought about by poverty, as they grow old. She joined ASHI, a KIVA field partner in the Philippines, to be able to access a loan. This opportunity will enable her to put up her own business, bandi making (coconut candy making), and be economically independent from her husband who is a farmer. Bandi is one of the famous delicacies of Antique province. Most of the customers buying this delicacy are tourists and they are buying bandi for a present when they go home to their own places. Profits she will be getting out of this business will be her means to augment her husband’s sporadic income. Most of her earnings will be saved for her and her husband’s needs in the future and some will be used to support her children’s family, which is also poor. Though her children no longer live with her, she can’t afford seeing them suffer because of poverty. Through loans she can request, she believes that the business she’ll be financing will bring change to her family's lives.

loans.use: To buy ingredients needed for bandi making (coconut candy making)

loans.name: Maria

Maria B. is from the village of Garang Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Maria is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products and dry goods in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Maria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Maria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and for daily needs.

About GDMPC:

loans.name: Benny

texts.en:
Benny is 44 years old and married to Alejandro, a farmer. They were blessed with eight children; one of them is married. They live in Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela.

Benny is engaged in a retail business on the school campus in their village where she has a small stall to in front of their house display her products. Her weekly net income is PHP 1,500. Every Saturday and Sunday she also sells various items in front of their house for additional income. She wants to access a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP17,000 for the expansion of her business and to purchase more products that she can sell.

loans.use: Additional capital for business expansion

The main source of income for the business comes from selling variety of products in the local community. Elda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Elda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. Elda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
This is Fely M., 66 years old. She seems to never get tired of the things she does. Her family lives in Pangarap Village, Caloocan City.

Fely has been in business for the last fifteen years. Through the years, she gets to add on new business ventures one after the other. She now has a small pharmacy and a general store where she sells purified drinking water in large plastic containers and soft drinks as well. She is earning P20,000 a month.

She is very thankful that her family now enjoys better living conditions as opposed to the poor life they had when they used to live amongst the squatter families in the metro.

Having become a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 was one of her treasured experiences. She currently needs a loan in the amount of P20,000 so she can purchase inventory for her store and pharmacy.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en: Bumi sells kerosene at retail prices to her various customers within her community in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 45 years old and she is married with 5 children. Her husband is an electrician. She is a hard-working woman. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Marionito

texts.en:
Marionito A. is from the town of Kingay Sur Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 37 years old. Marionito is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marionito owns and operates a transportation service and sells "tuba," coconut wine. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motor transportation services and selling "tuba" (coconut wine) to local community members. Marionito has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marionito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marionito has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Marionito is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Marionito from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase equipment to improve the business

To make a living, Vicenta owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of condiments such as onions, tomatoes, bell peppers, and others for sale. Vicenta has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In May 2009, Vicenta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vicenta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Vicenta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

loans.name: Petronilla

texts.en:
Petronilla is a 32-year-old married mother of two children living in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has run a tailoring and dress-making business for ten years. She earns some extra income through small-scale farming and selling water. She employs three people but would like to double the number of trainees. She is requesting Kes. 90,000 to buy more material. In the future, she would like to buy her own plot of land. She describes herself as hard-working.

About Faulu Kenya:

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy more material

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina, or “Ibing” as she is fondly called, is a resident of Brgy Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Armando Sr. and they were gifted with six children. Due to financial difficulty, most of their children only finished high school. The family's source of income is farming and they plant rice and vegetables. Sometimes, Armando works as construction worker.

As her way of helping her husband, Rosalina is engaged in selling onions, groceries, fish sauce and other commodities to earn a living. She started her business from a small capital and is able to earn a weekly income of PHP600. 

Rosalina wants to improve her business and in line with this she is asking for financial assistance from the Kiva lenders amounting to PHP5,000.  This will be of great help in purchasing additional commodities that she can offer to her customers. She hopes that with the support of the lenders, she can improve her small business and increase her income through her patience and sacrifices.

loans.use: Additional capital for her food production business.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin is 55 years old and married with three children. Her children are all in school.

Toyin sells kitchen utensils like plates, pots, spoons, and so on. She hopes for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more kitchen utensils to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils to sell.

loans.name: May

texts.en:
May is engaged in vending cooked snacks such as  fish balls, kikiams, hotdogs and refreshment drinks in their village. Aside from snacks, she also sells frozen foods like longganisa, tocino, hotdog and so on.  She is requesting a loan of PHP5,000 from the KIVA lenders to further expand her business. According to her, she will use the loan in purchasing more frozen foods and different snacks to sell.  This amount will help her make her business profitable.  

May is 26 years old.  She is married to Abraham, who works as a steel man in Manila.  She hopes that someday her husband will find a good job near their village.  May and her two children live in the village of Palattao, Naguilian, Isabela.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her frozen food and snack food business.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel M., 21 years old is a young farmer from Kapatungan, Trento, Agusan del Sur.  Her main crop is rice. She hopes that farming will provide her entire family income with an adequate supply food, clothing and other basic needs.  She longs for a good life for her family. She also maintains a small business raising pigs.  Aside from having a piggery, she sells used clothing and other items to earn extra income. She sells ready-to-wear products to be able to raise money and save for the education of her two children. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and buy farming necessities to grow her harvest and raise pigs.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Aya

texts.en:
Aya J. is currently in the business of selling rice, beans and pulses. She is requesting a loan to purchase dried fish to sell.  Aya is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 4 children and 3 of them attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to help meet her family's food expenses.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase dried fish to sell

loans.name: Lermalina

texts.en:
Lermalina is a vendor of fruits, vegetables and chicken in her village.  She is 48 years old and married to Nestor, an equipment operator in their village. They have two children. Their eldest is 24 years old, a high school graduate and the youngest is a nursing graduate. She hopes that her children will have a good future someday.

Lermalina delivers her merchandise in the market everyday. With her diligence, she was able to sustain the needs of her children.  For the continuous improvement of her business, she is now asking for a loan of PHP5,000 from the KIVA lenders which she will use for business expansion.

loans.use: Additional capital for business expansion

loans.name: Bukola

texts.en: Bukola is 33 years old and sells sarongs and bottles of wine. She is married with one child. Her husband works in a financial institution.She started this business in 2000 and is happy because her business is expanding. Bukola hopes to receive a loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more sarongs and bottles of wine to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of sarongs and bottles of wine to sell

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona D. is from the village of Balintawak St., Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 39 years old. Chona is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Chona owns & operates a business in the food sector making & selling food. Her main source of income from the business comes primarily from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Chona has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Chona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Chona is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Chona from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional food products to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty Q. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran Zamboanga DelSur. She is 63 years old. Betty is widowed and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Betty owns a specialized retail store where her main source of income is from selling vegetables. Betty has been engaged in her business for over three years and she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2007, Betty joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty successfully repaid her last loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. She used this previous loan to expand her business. Betty is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which she will use as additional capital for her business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Betty from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business.

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Ballara

texts.en:
Ballara D. J.., 24 years old, is planning to settle down soon and have a family. But before he will engage to marriage, he wants to have a very stable farm or business, which he could rely on to supply his wife and children adequate food, clothes and other basic needs. He is planning to enrich the soil of his farm and he is interested in methodologies to make his harvest double in size.  

Ballara is requesting a loan of PHP5000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will help in buying farming necessities. Receiving the loan is truly worthwhile because this will give him and his family an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is married to Jimmy and they were blessed with two children: Rosalie and Sheryl.  They are living a simple life in the village of Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. They belong to a poor family, but through hard work and sacrifices they have been able to support the education of their children who are both college graduates and are now working.  

Rosalinda manages her own sari-sari store (community-based store) while her husband works as a bus inspector. She wants to improve her small business to earn more and save for their future. Since she has little capital to invest in her store, she is asking for financial support from the Kiva lenders in the form of a loan of PHP5000.  She will use this loan to purchase additional merchandise for her store. She hopes for more business success.

loans.use: Additional capital for her small variety store

loans.name: Junrey

texts.en:
Junrey B. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 20 years old. Junrey is single. To make a living, he owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. Junrey's main source of income from this business comes from providing transportation services to local community members using his motor vehicle. Junrey has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Junrey joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Junrey is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand his transportastion service. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Junrey from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of his family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase parts materials needed to expand his transportation service

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
57 years old Jose B. grows rice for a living. This has been his family's livelihood since he first married his wife Meralinda. They have one child. He said, “ Farming is our only source of livelihood. Sometimes we failed to have a good harvest but we are resilient and able to survive the many challenges”. Aside from farming, Jose B. also earns income by selling drilling materials. 

He wants to expand his farming business. Now, he needs additional capital to buy more farming necessities and to pay for laborers who help prepare the soil for planting. The loan is truly helpful in sustaining this family livelihood in their pursuit of having an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Edmar

texts.en:
Edmar O. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 37 years old. Edmar is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Edmar owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling sugar, rice, salt shampoo, soap and etc. in the local community. Edmar has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Edmar joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edmar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to improve and expand her business. Edmar is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell in the local community. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Edmar from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Samuela

texts.en:
Samuela is married to Julius. She is 30 years old and gifted with two children: Joi Antonette, 10 years old, and Julius Jr., 8 years old. They live peacefully in the village of Palattao, Naguilian, Isabela.

Samuela has been selling frozen foods for four months. She sells them throughout their entire village on a house to house basis. Her starting capital was PHP 2,300; now, she wants to expand her business. She would like to borrow PHP 5,000, which is sufficient to expand her business. She hopes to get the chance to increase her income and thus sustain the growing needs of her family.

loans.use: additional capital with which to grow her business

loans.name: Alapaze

texts.en:
Alapase R. is currently in the business of selling beef, chickens, rice, etc. at a restaurant. She is requesting a loan to purchase fresh sweet potatoes and cassava.  

Alapase is 32 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 3 children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to continue to send her children to school and provide them with scholastic materials.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and the empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchasing fresh sweet potatoes and cassava

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara is 40 years old. She is married with a child. She sells drinks and stationery at various retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because it is highly competitive; she hopes to meet the requirement of her customers. She hopes for a loan of N 100,000, with which she will purchase more drinks and stationary. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more drinks and stationary

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma M. (in a white shirt at the right side of photo) lives in Pangarap Village Caloocan City, a progressive city in the northern tip of Manila.  She is 54 years old. Her husband Augusto is a carpenter. They have six children.  

Elma owns and manages a home-based workshop making dolls hand-sewn from fabric trimmings  She has been in this business for twenty years; now, she now has six employees working on shifts. Elma earns at least P 64,000.00 a month. Elma states that her family used live a poor life amongst the squatter communities in Manila; they were blessed to be included among the families relocated in Pangarap Village. Through the help of a religious missionary group, she was given the opportunity to get into business.
   
She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for four years. Currently, she needs a new loan in the amount of P 20,000.00 so that she can buy more scrap fabric and other raw materials for her business. She will also use part of the loan to purchase a few pieces of G.I. sheet to replace a dilapidated portion of their house’s roof.

She hopes to make her workshop a lot bigger in the future so she can be of help to many unemployed individuals. She also wishes to independently export her dolls.     

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchasing raw materials for doll making

Veronica has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 2,300 PHP a month.

Veronica is currently requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Veronica from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Bisi

Bisi is 48 years old and she is a widow with four children. She takes care of her children alone and she hopes to give them a quality education.

Bisi has a shop where she sells drinks and provisions. She hopes for a loan of N140,000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Nekaruut A Group

texts.en:
Nekaruut A is a group of seven farmers in Merbaun Village, Nekaruut Sub-Village, West Amarasi Sub-District, Kupang District of East Nusa, Tenggara Province. Merbaun Village is situated about 42 km from Kupang City.

The group is led by Herman T., a 36-year-old married man with three adorable children: Astri T., 14, in the second grade of junior high school; Zamrud, 5, in kindergarten; and Maria, 1. Herman and his family have lived in Merbaun Village for years. As the head of his family, Herman is responsible for meeting their daily needs. Therefore, he has been working as a truck driver for 14 years, usually delivering sand and stones for his customers. The income that he earns from this work is unstable as it depends on orders from customers. Besides working as a truck driver, Herman cultivates banana and coconuts on his farm, but he is only able to sell these products every six months. By selling agricultural products, he can only generate a small amount of income. Herman realizes that his children are growing up and they will need more and more money, both for their education as well as their daily needs.

Herman needs to find another way to support his family. He saw that his neighbors had joined the Cattle Fattening Program of Kiva partner TLM and after several cycles of this program they were able to better provide for their families. He got information from a relative about the TLM Cattle Fattening Program, which assists poor farmers in West Timor by providing a loan to buy young cattle to be fattened over a 12-month period. Herman thinks this program is a good way to improve his family's standard of living. So after discussing it with his nearest neighbors, they decided to form a group, called Nekaruut A.

Herman is requesting a loan of 3,400,000 IDR to buy young cattle to be fattened over a 12-month period. The other group members are also requesting loans to buy young cattle to fatten, as they also want to provide a better life for their beloved families.

loans.use: To buy young cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen C. is from the village of Purok 3, San Isidro, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 68 years old and married. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,942 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Helen joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Nekaruut B Group

texts.en:
Nekaruut B is a group of eight people from Merbaun Village, Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Merbaun Village is situated about 42 km from Kupang City, the capital city of East Nusa Tenggara Province. The last 6 km of road used to enter Merbaun Village is in a really bad condition. This is why it takes about two hours to drive from Kupang City to Merbaun.

There are many coconut, banana and betel nut trees growing in Merbaun Village. The local community relies on the agricultural sector to support their families. The challenge for the Merbaun community is the availability of public transport in the village. Such transport is only available twice a week, limiting the opportunities farmers have for going to market to sell their products. Generally, the houses in this area are constructed simply and have no electricity supply. Even though electricity is available in this area, the community cannot afford it as the installation cost is quite expensive.

Nekaruut B group is led by a 33-year-old farmer, Ferdinan P.. He is married and blessed with two children: Marthen P., 9, in the third grade of elementary school, and Iwan P., 7, in the first grade of elementary school. Like many other farmers, Ferdinan relies on farming to generate money to meet his family's needs. He usually sells coconuts and bananas from his own farm at the market. Sometimes the coconuts and bananas that Ferdinan brings to the market do not all sell, and he has to bring them back to the village and sell them at a cheaper price. This is the only way for him to make money as he doesn’t have any other business. For two years Ferdinan fattened cattle owned by an entrepreneur from Kupang, but he felt that the fee was insufficient to meet his family's needs. He really wants to better provide for his family but his lack of capital is the main issue.

The situation that Ferdinan faces motivated him to join the TLM cattle-fattening program. The hope for a better future and his experience in fattening cattle has given him the self-confidence to join the program. Ferdinan is requesting a loan of 3,400,000 IDR from Kiva partner TLM to buy young cattle to fatten in 12 months. He hopes that this loan will help him better meet his family's needs. The other group members are also requesting loans to buy young cattle. They hope their loans lead them to a better life.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin D. is 30 years old and owns and manages a small rice field in Kapatungan, Trento, Agusan del Sur. He has spent the majority of his time on the farm and is able to grow crops like rice to support his family. As a father, it’s always a challenge for him to provide all the needs for their home. He wants to do well in rice farming to be able to save money and send all his five children to school until they reach college.

He desires to increase the usual size of his harvest. To accomplish this, he would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to fund his farm to buy farming necessities in order to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Kanaan A Group

texts.en:
Asin K. R. is a 38 year old man. He leads the Kanaan A Group, which is composed of 8 people in Erbaun Village, East Amarasi Sub district, Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Erbaun Village is situated for about 52 Km from Kupang City near to the eastern coast of Timor Island. This village can be categorized as a remote village. The road leading to this village is in bad condition with many holes on it. This makes it difficult for public transportation to enter the village. Only trucks enter, but even they are only available once a week. 

Most of the community in Erbaun village relies on farming to generate income in order to meet their family's needs. But a part of the community, especially those living in coastal area, also try to dig sand to sell as the quality of sand in this village is quite good. This is another way for them to generate money.

Asin has been living in Erbaun Village since he was a child. Due to his parents' poverty, Asin was only able to have primary education. Consequently, he had to become a farmer because no other jobs were available to him.

Asin is a married to a 30 year old woman named Elkana. They have been blessed with two children. They are: Mesrin, 6 years old, in the first grade of elementary school, and Vivi, 4 years old and thus not at school yet.

Asin lives close to the coast. He and family live in a modest house, where the roof is made of palm leaves, the walls are composed of palm branches, the floor is mere dirt and there is no electricity. Asin likes farming better than digging sand as farming is his hobby. He usually sells bananas and coconuts at Inpres market in Kupang City once a week. His wife also helps him in generating money by selling their products. Even though both of them have worked hard to generate money, the income is only enough to meet their daily needs. They cannot save money. Asin and his wife are also challenged by competition in selling their goods.

This is the reason why Asin is interested in joining a cattle fattening program with the other group members. The availability of cattle food makes him even more enthusiastic about joining the program. He is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 3,300,000 to buy young cattle to be fattened for 12 months. He hopes that the cattle fattening program will enable him to cover all of his family needs. The other group members are also requesting a loan as they want to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: purchasing cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad is an energetic businesswoman engaged in vending different snacks in her village. She sells quail eggs and cooked snacks in the afternoon. In addition, she also sells Tupperware products for additional income. She has been in this business for five.  She needs more capital to sell her products.  She is requesting a loan of PHP5,000 from KIVA lenders.

Caridad is 40 years old and married to Jessie, a farmer. They are blessed with five children who are all studying. She aims to succeed in her business to supplement her family’s income. She hopes to give all her children a complete education so that they’ll live a better life someday.

loans.use: To be used as additional capital for business expansion

loans.name: Kanaan B Group

texts.en:
Kanaan B Group is a group of 7 farmers in Erbaun Village, Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Erbaun is a remote village which is situated about 52 Km from the capital city of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Similar to many other rural areas in West Timor, most of community in Erbaun Village supports their family life by farming. 

Kanaan B Group is led by Apsalom R., a 26 year old single man. He has been living in Erbaun Village since he was a child. In Erbaun, Apsalom lives with his parents and two of his sisters in their modest house constructed with a palm leaf roof, branch wall and dirt floor. His father, aged 65 years and his mother, aged 60 years, are both poor farmers. They couldn’t afford to finance Apsalom’s education. As a result, Apsalom couldn’t complete his primary school. He only attended school up to the second grade of primary school. Apsalom then chose to help his parents in farming. He has to work hard to help his parents and to finance his sisters. 

Apsalom works everyday at the farm. He sells agriculture produce such as coconuts and bananas at the market. The income generated from selling these produce is given to his parents to cover their daily needs. To better meet his family needs, Apsalom once joined with the local fisherman for fishing. But it was only for a year. After that he became a truck driver for some time. Apsalom then moved to Kupang City and worked as a building laborer. The reason why Apsalom chose these types of work is because his parents are getting older and he doesn’t have a heart to let his parents work hard to bring their coconuts and bananas from the farm to the market to sell at their advanced age.

According to Apsalom, currently the profits from the farm are lower than usual. As a result, the income generated from selling coconuts and bananas is sometimes insufficient to cover the family needs. His experience as a building laborer in Kupang City helps him in generating some money when a community member asks him to repair their house. But this is an irregular income source for him.

The difficulties that Apsalom faces have motivated him to find another way to support his parents and his sisters. One of the alternatives that have become his preference is to raise and fatten cattle. To raise cattle, Apsalom needs capital to buy the young cattle and he can not afford it as poor farmer. This is the reason why Apsalom is interesting in joining the cattle fattening program. Together with the other members of Kanaan B Group, they are requesting a loan to buy young cattle to be raised and fattened over a 12 month period. Apsalom is requesting a loan of IDR 3,400,000. He hopes that this loan will help him in better providing his parents and sisters needs.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be raised and fattened

loans.name: Kodi

texts.en:
Kodi A. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more yeast and sugar for brewing.  Kodi is 47 years old and is married. Her husband that is a manufactures charcoal. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar at the nearby market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to purchase more yeasts and sugar for brewing

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en: 58 year old Vicenta D. is a former KIVA client. She needs additional capital to be able to sustain and grow her rice farming business. With her previous  loan she was able to grow her rice and have an abundant harvest. She hopes to be able to make her second KIVA loan and is now applying for a loan amounting to Php 8,000 to fund her farm. She said that last season she had a very good harvest because she had good financial condition and was able to buy the things needed to manage her crops. With this second loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. she will buy the farming necessities and pay the laborers who help prepare the farm for planting.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
Ariel C. is from the village of Zone 1, Camarahan, Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 33 years old. Ariel is single. To make a living, Ariel makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling grilled meat such as chicken legs, chicken feet, chicken intestines, pork, chicken liver, etc. in the local community. Ariel has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ariel joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Ariel is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Ariel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, or Opin as she is fondly called, is a resident of Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Valentino; they have four children, three female and one male. They are all in school. The eldest is in college while the others are in secondary and elementary levels. As parents, Josephine and Valentino want all of their children to finish their studies and find stable jobs someday. 

Farming is their main source of income. Their crops include rice, vegetables and corn. To assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family, Josephine decided to begin selling fish, meat and vegetables in their village. With a small amount of capital, she was then able to start her own business in the public market of Diadi. Through her patience and sacrifices, she earns a net income of PHP 700 a week, which she carefully budgets for the daily needs of their family and the tuition fees and allowances of their children. 

She wants to borrow PHP 5,000 from the Kiva lenders for the improvement of her business. Through the loan, she can purchase more merchandise that she believes will result in an increased income.

loans.use: improving her food selling business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina C. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old. Gina is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Gina makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products as well as variety of beverages in the community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Gina joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Gina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Hadijatu

texts.en: Hadijatu is 50 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband is a mechanic. She sells sarongs and foodstuffs in her stall in Lagos State, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan amount of N 140,000, with which she will purchase more sarongs and foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more sarongs and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Felicino

texts.en:
Felicino S., 58 years old, is still managing and tilling small rice field a short distance away from their village. Farming is his best skill. The farm is what he hopes could help him supply his family with the food, clothes and other basic things that they need. Now, he is constantly attempting to surpass the size of his previous harvest.

He needs additional capital for his business. Receiving a loan of PHP 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. will be of great help, especially since he doesn’t have the money to support his business anymore. The loan will not just help him sustain his livelihood but will give him an increased income as well.

loans.use: financing his farm

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita C. is from the village of NHA Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 53 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nenita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income is from selling vitamins such as vitamin C tablets in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month.

In 2009, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nenita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her enterprise. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia is a store owner in her village. She is 43 years old and married to Feliciano who is managing their rice farming business. Florencia would like to expand her business to meet the demands of her customers.  With this in mind, she is requesting a loan of PHP9,000 from the KIVA lenders to purchase additional merchandise for her store.  

She hopes that through the business capital that she is requesting, her business will continue to grow and allow her family to have a more progressive way of living.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Khanlar

texts.en: Khanlar has been in the house repair business for 5 years. He was born in 1966. Khanlar lives in Baku city, is married and has 2 children. He is now requesting a loan of 2000 AZN to buy necessary tools and supplies to improve his house repair business.

loans.use: to buy necessary tools and supplies to improve his house repair business

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde is a widow and she is saddled with the responsibility of taking care of her 3 children alone. She sells sachet water and sarongs at retail prices to her customers in her community in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a hard working woman and she is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes to receive the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more supplies of sachet water and sarongs to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of sachet water and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Hannah Wanjiku

texts.en:
Hannah is married to Paul and they have four children; Charles, Michael, Lydia and Naomi.

Hannah was introduced to KADET by existing clients and she has no previous credit history. She has been in the retail sales business as well as the rental homes business for seven years. In her retail shop, she sells mostly cereals (maize). With her loan, Hannah will purchase more stock to sell from her retail shop.

The clients' area of business is in a slum and her customers are the residents of the slum. With the extra profits Hannah hopes to earn as a result of this loan, she will put up more rental houses. Hannah believes she is hardworking and hopes to educate her children.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more stock of cereals and other items to sell in her retail shop.

loans.name: Akouavi Solange

texts.fr: C. Akouavi Solange est née vers 1971 à Pobè, dans le Département du Plateau. Solange est mariée à TOULASSI Clément,un chauffeur. Solange et Clément n'ont encore pas d'enfant mais ils ont en charge un enfant qui est scolarisé. La famille vit à Womey, un quartier de la Commune d'Abomey-Calavi non loin de Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. C'est le mari de Solange qui assure les charges de la famille. Ce qui permet à Solange d'investir les revenus de son activité dans celle-ci pour mieux la développer. En effet, Solange vend par le système de distribution, des produits vivriers (tubercules d'igname, maïs, mil, sorgho, haricot, etc.). C'est à Glazoué, un des marchés internationaux de produits vivriers du Bénin que Solange s'approvisionne en ces différents produits. Solange veut renforcer son fonds de roulement pour pouvoir répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante. Alors, Solange sollicite son premier crédit de ALIDé pour atteindre son objectif.
texts.en:
C. Akouavi Solange was born around 1971 in Pobè, in Plateau County. She is married to TOULASSI Clément, a chauffeur. She and Clément still do not have any children, but they support a child who is in school. The family lives in Womey, a district in the community of Abomey-Calavi, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Solange’s husband is the one who ensures that family expenses are covered. This allows Solange to invest the revenues from her business to develop it further. Basically, she sells staple foods (yam tubers, corn, millet, sorghum, beans, etc.) through the distribution system. Glazoué, one of the international markets of Benin for staple goods, is where she stocks up on these different goods. Solange wants to bolster her working capital to be able to respond better to the demands of her growing customer base. And so, she’s requesting her first ALIDé loan to attain her goals.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn, beans, millet, sorghum, and yam tubers

loans.name: Antony  Njoroge

texts.en:
Antony is separated and he takes care of his two children, Robbin and Allan.

He was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he has no previous credit history. Antony will use this loan to increase his stock of second-hand clothes and linens, specifically bed sheets and pillow cases.

Antony's business location is densely populated with middle-income residents. With the extra income he hopes to establish another similar business in an identified strategic area.

His dream is to have a chain of imported new bedding and carpets. He describes himself as business-oriented, hardworking, focused, and determined.

loans.use: Increase his stock of second-hand bed sheets and pillow cases to sell

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna T. is a 29 year old rice farmer. She has a small rice field, which helps her and her husband provide all the needs of their household. In addition to rice, she has started to raise pigs close to their home.  She engages in multiple businesses in order to supplement their daily income. She has been a CEVI client for quite a long time now. She conscientiously pays all her obligations and has maintained a good repayment record in CEVI's micro credit program.

She hopes to grow her business but needs additional capital to do this. She is applying for a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to fund her farm and buy the farming necessities. In this way, she is assured to have an abundant harvest on her farm that her family will  enjoy.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Madredonia

texts.en:
“A man without determination will not reach his destination”, this is the guiding principle of Madredonia, a responsible mother and wife of Prudencio.  Their family is living in the village of  Uddiawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. They have three children: Sheryl, Rochelle S. and Rachell.  As parents, they want their children to become successful and have a higher standard of living.  Hence, they sacrifice everything just to send them to school and provide them with their educational needs.  

Her husband is the one who cultivates their farm by planting rice, vegetables and corn, while Madredonia engages herself in the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables as her way of helping her husband earn a living for their family.  

With only a small capital reserve, she buys products from the farmers in their village then sells them in their village and in the public market of Solano at retail prices. She want to continue and improve her business so she is asking for a loan from the KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP5,000.  This will be used to buy more fruits and vegetables. She hopes that with her patience and sacrifices, she will be able to improve her business and give their children the best education possible.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosielyn

texts.en:
Rosielyn T., 22 years old is a rice farmer. She started helping her husband till their small hectare rice field to be able to contribute a little in the family income. Aside from doing the household chores, she has to work hard so she to supplement their income. The income they make from growing rice pays the daily expenses in their home. Some of their harvests are used for their own consumption while the rest are sold for income.  

She requested a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her rice farm by buying all the farming necessities to grow her harvest. Rosielyn also desires to save up for her children's education.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Shakirat

texts.en: Shakirat is 32 years old, married and has a child. She sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. Shakirat hopes to expand her business in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of N170,000 to purchase more kerosene supplies to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of kerosene to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth Mbulwa

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married to Salim and they have two children: Antony and Carolyne, who are 15 and 7 years old respectively.

She was introduced to KADET through existing clients and has no previous credit history. Elizabeth has been in the embroidery business for six years. She will use her loan to start a cereal sales business (maize) in order to diversify her income.

She runs her business is in a slum that is highly populated. Elizabeth's clients are residents of the area. Elizabeth also supplies embroidery items to other towns. 

With the extra profits, she intends to buy more machines for embroidery. In the future, Elizabeth aspires to open an embroidery school. She describes herself as hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. For more information on KADET, visit www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Starting a cereal sales business to diversify her income

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann C. is a 37 year-old rice farmer from Kapatungan Agusan Del Sur. Her eldest child is 20 years old, but is not able to go to college. Mary Ann is very optimistic that someday she will be able to grow her farm. She hopes to be able to meet all of her family's needs with the income that she is going to make from her rice field. 

She is requesting a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy the farming necessities and pay for the equipment they rented to prepare the land.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda or Luz is 55 years old.  She is married to Jaime and blessed with three children.  They are living in the village of Uddiawan, Solano,Nueva Vizcaya. 

Her husband works as a carpenter and steel man at Communal, Solano, and Nueva Vizcaya, while she manages their small sari-sari store (community based variety store) business. She sells different grocery items and frozen foods in their village from Monday to Saturday. Through hard work and sacrifices, she can earn a net income of PHP 4,500.00 a month which she can budget to meet the needs of their family and also as a rolling capital for her business and to meet the tuition fees of her children. 

At present she would like to borrow  a loan amount of PHP5,000.00 that she needs to purchase more stocks for her store.  She is hoping that the lender will grant her loan request so that she can pursue her business plans.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Floridah Museo

texts.en:
Floridah is married to Harrison and they have two children, Pauline and Idaya, ages 16 and 10 years old respectively.

Floridah was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she is servicing her second loan in KADET. Her credit history is perfect. Floridah has been in the clinic business for eight years.She will use this loan to purchase additional stock of drugs to supply her customers. 

Floridah's area of business is in a slum in the industrial area. With the extra profits she hopes to earn, she plans to build rental houses and diversify her income. In the future, Floridah aspires to own a hospital as she believes she is hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy additional supplies of drugs for the clinic

loans.name: Alabi

texts.en: At the age of 35, Alibi is married and has 4 children. He lives in Ogbomoso, in Oyo State, Nigeria where he rents out musical instruments for parties and celebrations. He is requesting a loan of 50, 000 to purchase more instruments for renting. He says a big thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more musical instruments to rent.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita V. is from the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 59 years old. Anita is married and has  adult-aged children.
