loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is twenty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all enrolled in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Ramatu works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities.

Ramatu sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. She has been in business for fifteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Seth

texts.en: Seth is fifty years old. He is married with two children who are both in senior high school. He sells hardware and has been in business for the last eight years. He has in stock goods like paintbrushes, nails, roofing sheets, hammers, pliers, etc. and sells in the community market and sometimes hawks them during the market days. He says he lacks adequate working capital to buy stock from the market. He requests the loan to enable him to procure stock. He takes delivery of goods from Kumasi and retails them to his customers. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To procure useful tools and materials such as polish, glue, sandpaper etc.

loans.name: Barikisu

texts.en:
Barikisu is twenty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Barikisu is a petty trader. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. She sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Barikisu has been in business for over twelve years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Barikisu

texts.en:
Barikisu is forty-three years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a petty trader.

Barikisu sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. She has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en: Vincent is 42 years old. He is single with no children. He has been a supplier of palm oil for three years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts. He buys them in bulk from the surrounding villages and supplies to food vendors to prepare their meals. He wants to use the loan to buy more palm oil in gallons to increase his customer base hence his profit margin. Vincent would be grateful for your support and hopes to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil to sell

loans.name: Salawu

texts.en:
Salawu is 50 years old and married with 6 children. He lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

Salawu owns a printing press where he does printing work. He is requesting for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more printing materials. He says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more printing materials

loans.name: Rasikatu

texts.en:
Rasikatu is married with 4 children. She is 40 years old. She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

She sells charcoal and palm oil. She has been in LAPO for two years. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more charcoal and palm oil to sell. She says thanks you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and palm oil

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is 59 years old and a married woman with four children. Currently all her children are fully independent. She sells frozen foods such as chicken, mutton, fish, sausages, etc. in the local market where she lives. She started this business a year ago. She takes delivery of stock from Kumasi in bulk and supplies to her customers. She does not have adequate funds to support her business. This has affected her operation, especially in the face of increasing food prices.

With the loan, she wants to purchase more cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, and pork to enable her to raise enough income to expand her sales. She dreams of being the number one supplier of frozen food in her community.

loans.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, mutton, etc.

loans.name: Fauzia

texts.en:
Fauzia is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice with stew. She sells on a table top in front of her house.

Fauzia has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is 31 years, married and a mother of two kids who are currently schooling. She lives with her family in a rented apartment. She is a petty trader who has sold lace clothes, lingerie items like brasieres, other underwear, etc. for the past six years. She requests the loan to augment her working capital to buy more stock of lace clothes, slippers, lingerie, and dressing bags to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to raise more income to support her family.

loans.use: To buy bales of clothing materials, ladies' bags and slippers

loans.name: Acia

texts.en:
Acia is forty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Acia is a petty trader. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. She sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Acia has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Women Power Group

texts.en:
Women Power is a group of 5 borrowers led by Korpo D.. Korpo is a 28-year-old widow with 3 children. Her children are 7-12 years old and their educational levels are 3rd -5th grade. She is illiterate due to poverty. Korpo and her kids live in Ziggida, a small town close Zorzor, a district in Lofa county in northern Liberia.

Korpo’s business is selling general goods. She buys general goods like soft drinks, salt, and candles wholesale, and sells them at retail from a table to residents of Ziggida. She has been running this business for 5 years and hopes to improve her business. Korpo sells good products and also talks to her customers in a good manner during transactions in order encourage them to continue buying from her.

Korpo started this business with little funds given to her by her husband before his death. She happens to be a young woman who lost her husband 4 years after marriage, and is now left to take of the kids alone. Korpo‘s little business has been taking care of her family's needs, but it is not enough to give them good future.

She needs this loan in order to purchase more general goods wholesale so she can earn more profit to improve her business. Korpo dreams of giving her children a better education and of changing their living condition totally.

loans.use: To purchase more general goods to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is twenty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Lucy is a petty trader. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. She sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Lucy has been in business for barely one year and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Asana

texts.en:
Asana is twenty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to five children. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to provide for the family.

Asana is a petty trader. She sells yams. She procures the goods from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina is 29 years old, and she is married and the mother of one child. She also has her sister’s daughter living with her, making two children. The children are currently in school. She is a petty trader who sells used clothes. Her husband and kids are very proud of her because of the enormous contribution she makes in the home.

Selling of used clothing is a very big market in Ghana, as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore selling used clothing has created a market for many women like her. She has been in business since last year and gets her stock of goods from Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children’s educational needs and to rent a store to sell out of. She hopes to repay her loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Talata

texts.en:
Talata is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to seven children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to provide for the family.

Talata is a trader. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. She sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Talata has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is 30 years old and a petty trader. She is married and the mother of two children who are currently in school. She sells onions, tomatoes, peppers, etc. on the top of a table in the local market of Goaso where she lives. She takes delivery of stock from the surrounding villages and sometimes Kumasi, which is about forty kilometers from Goaso.

Patience is requesting the loan to enable her to buy more tomatoes, onions, and peppers to grow her business and to scale up the business. She hopes to increase her savings to support the children’s education to give them a future and hope.

loans.use: to buy increased stock of onions, tomatoes, and peppers

loans.name: Wuwa

texts.en:
Wuwa B. is currently in the business of selling perfumes in a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more perfumes at her shop to sell. Wuwa is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more perfumes at her shop

loans.name: Ayishetu

texts.en: Ayishetu is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to eight children. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is a petty trader. She sells bags of charcoal. Ayishetu procures the goods from nearby communities. She supplies to food vendors and retailers. She has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure bags of charcoal in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is fifty-five years old; she is a widowed mother of six children. One is currently in school whilest the rest are working. She believes in hard work, and she is dedicated to her work as a primary antidote to minimizing poverty. She owns and operates a local restaurant and sells local foods like 'fufu' and 'banku'. 'Fufu' is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, taken with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains, and it is taken with hot pepper or soup.

Mary wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, etc.

loans.name: Kaku

texts.en:
Kaku C. is currently in the business of selling charcoal out of her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Kaku is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a police man. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Zenabu

texts.en: Zenabu is forty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to help her husband provide for the family financially. She is a trader. Zenabu trades in cola nuts. She procures bags of cola nuts (seed pods from African evergreen trees) from nearby communities and sells at the local market. She also supplies other retailers. Zenabu has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to procure cola nuts in bulk. She is hopeful of giving her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cola nuts

loans.name: Stand Strong Group

texts.en:
Yassah D. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called “Stand Strong”.

Yassah is 45 years old married with six children aged 15 to 30 years old and with educational levels of 7th through 12th grade. She and her family live in Ziggida Town, a small town close to Zorzor, a district in Lofa County, Northern Liberia. She is illiterate due to poverty.

Yassah’s business is her palm oil sales. She buys palm oil wholesale and sells retail in bottles on a table to residents of her town. She has been running this business for six years and is hoping to have a shop of her own. She sells quality palm oil and also talks to her customers with a good manner during transactions in order encourage them to continue buying from her.

Yassah is a very strong and caring mother who doesn’t depend on her husband for financial support but rather takes care of the family so that her husband will be proud of her. Her business has been her life. She was doing a better business before the civil crisis, but lost everything.

Yassah needs this loan in order to purchase more palm oil wholesale to acquire more profit to improve her business. She dreams of giving her husband help in supporting her children in school and of improving their living standard.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil wholesale to improve her business

loans.name: Rahinatu

texts.en: Rahinatu is twenty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to one girl, who is in school. She lives with her daughter and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially provide for the family. Rahinatu is a trader. She trades in jewels. She procures the goods from nearby communities and hawks to sell at the local market. Rahinatu has been in business for over eight years and wants a loan to procure jewels in bulk. She is hopeful of giving her children the best  education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy jewels in bulk

loans.name: Kulida

texts.en:
Kulida J. is currently in the business of selling onions and green vegetables. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of onions to sell.  Kulida is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a secretary. She has five children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by stocking beans and rice to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of onions to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 45 years old and a mother with three children. Her children are currently in school. To support her household, she has been selling cereals like beans and groundnuts to her loyal customers in the community market. She says that the selling of these products is very lucrative and that, with her five years of selling experience, she believes her dream will come true. She takes delivery of stock from the farming communities. She wants the loan to expand her inventory, which will enable her to make a good income to support her family, especially in their education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals like groundnuts and beans

loans.name: Antaiza

texts.en:
Antaiza J. is currently in the business of selling bread, green vegetables and groundnut phaste (spread or paste), and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of pulses (peas, beans, etc.) to sell.  Antaiza is 32 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has four children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bigger shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of pulses (peas, beans, etc.) to sell

loans.name: Fa

texts.fr:
Madame Fa G. voudrait investir dans le secteur d'aviculture avec sa crédit de 100.000 CFA.  Elle est une résidente de Camberene, une banlieue de Dakar pas loin de la mer.  Madame G. envisage une augmentation de revenu de 30.000 CFA par mois avec son crédit.  Elle est mariée avec des enfants.

Madame G. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Fa G. would like to invest in the field of poultry farming with a loan of 100,000 CFA. She is a resident of Camberene, a suburb of Dakar not far from the sea. Ms. G. foresees an increase in revenue of 30,000 CFA per month with this loan. She is married and has children. Ms. G. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Programme de développement de l'infant et de la famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms as compared to ordinary loans. Since the establishment of the agreement in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr:
Madame Astou P. habite dans la  zone de Camberene une localité situe au nord de Dakar depuis  plusieurs années.  Sa principale activité exercée est la couture mais elle est surtout orientée dans la commercialisation de boubous et de tissus. Elle capitalise une expérience de trois ans .Elle est mariée et parent bénéficiaire.  Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs qui sera destine a l achat de chaussures  et d autres articles divers pour diversifier ses marchandises et élargir son marche.  Ainsi elle pourra augmenter ses bénéfices mensuels de 10 000 frs. 
Madame ASTOU P. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Astou P. has lived in the zone of Camberene, an area situated north of Dakar, for several years. Her main activity is dressmaking, but she is especially turning towards selling boubous (wide-sleeved West African robes) and fabric. She draws on three years of experience in this field. She is married and a parent beneficiary (of the U-IMCEC loan program described below). She is seeking a loan of 150,000 francs, which will be used to buy shoes and various other items to diversify her merchandise and enlarge her business. In this way, she will be able to increase her monthly profits by 10,000 francs. Ms. Astou P. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Programe for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF in French) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms as compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's inception in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To diversify her goods

loans.name: Ndiaplay

texts.fr:
Madame Nidapaly N. est une commerçant de boubou et tissus en Camberene, Dakar.  Avec son prêt de 100.000 CFA, elle voudrait augmenter son fond roulement pour acheter des nouveaux tissus pour son petit entreprise.  Elle est mariée avec deux enfants.
Madame N. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Ndiaplay N. is a retailer of boubous (wide-sleeved West African robes) and fabric in Camberene, Dakar. With a loan of 100,000 CFA, she would like to increase her working capital to buy new fabric for her small business. She is married with two children. Ms. N. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Program for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF in French) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms, as compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's inception in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To enlarge her stocks of merchandise

loans.name: Senya

texts.en:
Senya J. is currently in the business of selling tea and bread at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more sugar and milk to sell.  Senya is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has six children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy foodstuffs like beans and rice etc to cook and sell in her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar and milk to sell

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame Aminata T. est une marchante de légumes au marché de Camberene, une banlieue de Dakar.  Elle a plus que 5 ans d'expérience sur le marché et elle voudrait bien augmenter son fond de roulement pour élargir son marché.  Elle est marié avec des enfants.  

Madame T. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Aminata T. is a retailer of vegetables at the market in Camberene, a suburb of Dakar. She has more than 5 years of experience in this field, and she would like to increase her working capital in order to enlarge her business. She is married and has children. Ms. T. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Program for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF in French) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms, as compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's inception in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in enlarging her stock of vegetables

loans.name: Nafisha

texts.en:
Nafisha R. is currently in the business of selling fish and onions and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell.  Nafisha is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a soldier. She has six children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and rent it out.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Anta Mbaye

texts.fr:
Madame Anta  Mbaye  S. est une commerçante de légumes et de poisons  qui a exerce cet  activité pendant sept ans. C est une femme mariée  qui habite a Camberene  ce qui lui facilite l approvisionnement en poissons  du a la proximité avec la mer. Elle sollicite un prêt de 50 000 frs en vue d augmenter  son fond de roulement et éventuellement accroitre ses revenus  mensuels de 15 000 frs.
Madame Anta Mbaye S. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Anta Mbaye S. is a retailer of vegetables and fish, and has been running her business for seven years. She is a married woman living in Camberene, and this location helps her obtain supplies of fish due to its proximity to the sea. She is seeking a loan of 50,000 francs with the goal of increasing her working capital and eventually raising her monthly income by 15,000 francs. Ms. Anta Mbaye S. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Program for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF in French) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms, as compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's inception in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Women Tie Your Wist Group

texts.en:
Larwuo M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Women Tie Your Wist."  She is 40 years old and a widow with three children ages 3-13, in kindergarten to fifth grade. She is illiterate due to poverty.  Larwuo and her children lives in Ziggida, a small town close Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Larwuo sells rice. She buys rice wholesale from farmers and sells retail by the cup to residents.  She has been in business for three year and hopes to improve her sales.  Larwuo treats her customers well so they continue buying from her.

During the Liberian civil crisis, Larwuo lost her husband and her hopes and dream were shattered with the burden and poverty.  She kept her focus and was motivated by the need to take care of her children.  Larwuo needs this loan in order to purchase more rice to improve her sales.  She dreams of educating her children and building them a house.

loans.use: Purchase more rice wholesale to resell.

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr: Madame Astou M.  sollicite pour la premiere fois un prêt de 50 000 frs pour augmenter le fond avec lequel elle gere son activite de de commerce de poissons au marche de Camberene.Elle est mariee et mere d un enfant.ELLE  emprunte  50 000 frs pour augmenter  son fond .Ainsi elle pourra accroitre ses benefices de 25 000 frs chaque mois.Madame Astou M. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Astou M. is seeking her first loan of 50,000 francs to increase the capital she uses to run her business selling fish at the market in Camberene. She is married and has one child. She would like to borrow 50,000 francs to increase her capital. In this way, she will be able to increase her profits by 25,000 francs each month. Ms. Astou M. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Program for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF in French) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms, as compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's inception in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: God Gives Group

texts.en:
Eyea F. is the leader of the five member group God Gives.  She is 29 years old and a single mother of two children ages two and 10.  The oldest is in third grade.  She is illiterate due to poverty.  Eyea and her children live in Ziggida Town in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Eyea buys dry fish wholesale and sells retail on a table to residents.  She has been in business for two year and hopes to move to a bigger table.  Eyea serves her customers with respect so they continue buying from her.

Eyea takes her business very seriously because it is her only means of income for her and her kids.  She is facing financial difficulties because her business is small.  When she uses funds to pay for school fees it bring her sales down.  But with hard work she is maintaining her business.

She needs this loan to purchase more dry fish to sell.  Eyae dreams of giving her children a better education and moving to the capital city, Monrovia.

loans.use: Purchase more dryfish wholesale to sell.

loans.name: Fama

texts.fr: Madame Fama  M. evolue depuis trois ans dans le commerce de de boubous et de tissus.Elle est mariee et mere d un enfant.C est son premier crédit sollicite car elle souhaiterait renforcer ses marchandises pour prevoir l augmentation de la demande  a l approche de la fete de tabaski.AAinsi elle pourra voir ses benefices augmenter de 20 000 frs mensuellement.Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des Madame Fama M. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Fama M. has been developing a business selling boubous (wide-sleeved West African robes) and fabrics for three years. She is seeking her first loan because she hopes to increase her stock of merchandise to anticipate the rise in demand with the approaching festival of Tabaski (Eid-al-Adha). In this way, she will be able to see her profits rise by 20,000 francs per month. Ms. Fama M. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) and the Program for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF in French) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community, and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can benefit from loans having more flexible terms, as compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's inception in December 2008, 120 parents have received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Telesfora

texts.en:
Telesfora D. is from the town of Kinuman Sur in Ozamiz City. She is 55 years old. Telesfora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Telesfora owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products and dried good products in the local community. Telesfora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Telesfora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Telesfora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Telesfora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP that she will use to expand her business. This will be Telesfora's fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Bigue

texts.fr:
Madame Bigue D. est une femme mariee mere d un enfant qui s active dans la vente de poissons afin de  satisfaire la demande de sa clientele.Avec ce pret elle aura l opportunite de maaximiser ses benefices en passant d un montant de 80 000 frs a 90 000 frs chaque mois.
 Madame Bigue D.  est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF)  Seydina  Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bigue D. is a married woman and the mother of one child who works at selling fish so as to satisfy the demand of her clientele. With this loan, she will have the opportunity of maximizing her profit, going from the sum of 80,000 Frs to 90,000 Frs per month. Mrs. Bigue D. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC and the Program for the Development of Children and the Family (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF is attempting to reduce poverty within the community and especially to protect children coming from underprivileged families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of the latter can take advantage of loans with more flexible conditions than usual. Since the agreement went into effect in December of 2008, 120 parents have received a loan for amounts between 50,000 and 150,000 Frs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to her working capital

loans.name: Maty

texts.fr:
Madame Maty  M. habite dans la localite de Camberene et espere avec le premier crédit qu elle va solliciter ameliorer  les conditions de vie de sa famille.Par consequent elle emprunte 150 000 frs pour renforcer son stock de de produits d entretien  et autres produits divers  qu elle commercialise.Elle est mariee et mere de trois enfants.Cest son premier prêt et elle compte ameliorer ses benefices qui pourront passer de45 000 frs a 60 000 frs chaque mois.


Madame Maty M. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF)  Seydina  Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maty M. lives in the Camberene area and hopes to use this first loan that she is requesting to improve living conditions for her family. Thus, she is borrowing 150,000 Frs to bolster her stock of cleansing products and various other items that she sells. She is married and the mother of 3 children. This is her first loan and she is counting on increasing her profit which should go from 45,000 to 60,000 Frs per month.

Mrs. Maty M. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC and the Program for the Development of Children and the Family (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF is attempting to reduce poverty within the community and especially to protect children coming from underprivileged families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of the latter can take advantage of loans with more flexible conditions than is usually the case. Since the agreement went into effect in December of 2008, 120 parents have received a loan for amounts between 50,000 and 150,000 Frs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to her working capital

loans.name: Bobei Group

texts.en:
Krubo F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Bobei. She is 40 years old and married with five children ages 2-16.  She is illiterate due to poverty.   Krubo and her family live in Ziggida Town, in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Krubo sells palm oil. She buys wholesale and sells retail in bottles on a table to residents.  She has been in business for three year and hopes to have a shop of her own.  Krubo serves her customers with respect and also talks to them during transaction in order encourage them to continue buying from her.

Krubo and her family are poor but have great dreams of becoming successful. She has been a good mother to her children.  Her husband is a farmer, but his income is low.  She needs this loan to purchase more palm oil to sell.  She dreams of supporting her children in school and change their living standard.

loans.use: Purchase palm oil wholesale to resell.

loans.name: Women Blessing Group

texts.en:
Philip D. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women Blessing. He is 37 years old and married with four children between the ages of 4 and 18. His children's educational levels range from kindergarten to 6th grade. He is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to poverty.

Philip and his family live in the Ziggida Town, a small town close Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Philip’s business is the sale of rice. He buys bags of rice wholesale from farmers and sells retail by cup to residents of Ziggida Town. He has been running this business for three years and is hoping to improve business. Philip sells quality rice and serves his customers with respect in order to encourage them to continue buying from him

Philip is a hardworking father who cares about his family's well-being. He started selling rice during his high school days. He paid his school fees and maintained his business. Because of poverty, Philip took care of himself as a youth and now, he doesn’t want his children to encounter what he went through as a youth. He believes that every child has the right to a comfortable upbringing.
 
He needs this loan in order to purchase more rice wholesale to acquire more profit to improve business. Philip dreams of giving his children a better education and moving to the capital in Monrovia, Liberia.

loans.use: To purchase more rice wholesale to acquire more profit to improve business

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake is married with five children. She is 45 years old. She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria, where she sells sarongs. She has been in this business for the past 15 years. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs

loans.name: Alima

texts.fr:
Madame Alima  M.  exerce l activité de vente de beignets dans le but de soutenir son mari et d améliorer les conditions de vie de sa petite famille. Ainsi elle souhaiterait acheter des  chaussures  et des tissus afin d élargir la gamme de marchandises qu’elle commercialise. Elle emprunte  150 000 frs
C est son premier financement.
Madame Alima M. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF)  Seydina  Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alima M. sells fritters so as to help her husband support their family and improve their little family's living conditions. Thus, she would like to buy shoes and cloth so as to expand the range of merchandise she sells. She is borrowing 150,000 Frs. This is her first loan.

Mrs. Alima M. is a beneficiary of the Protocol between Kiva Partner U-IMCEC and the Development Program for Children and Families "Seydina Issa Laye". This Program seeks to reduce poverty within the community and especially to protect children from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these families can benefit from loans with more flexible terms than ordinary loans. Since the start of this Protocol in December 2008, 120 parents have received loans in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 CFA francs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: diversifying the products she sells

loans.name: Musurat

texts.en: Musurat sells children's shoes, clothes and bags in Oyo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for over 20 years. Musurat is 42 years old and married with four children. Musurat is soliciting a loan of 70,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more children's shoes, clothes and bags. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more children's shoes, clothes and bags

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 35-year-old widow who lives in Runyenjes Embu, Kenya. She has two children. Beatrice has spent all her finances raising her children after the death of her husband more than three years ago. Hers has been a life of struggle, but she thanks God for overcoming all the difficulties.

Beatrice runs a boutique in Runyenjes town, a venture she initiated in 2008. She appreciates the fact that she has been able to get access to K-MET loans to improve her business. This has really changed her life. She periodically travels to Nairobi to get most of her stock. She mainly sells children's, ladies' and men’s clothing. Beatrice hopes to use her next loan of Kshs 40,000 to enable her to purchase more stock of clothes currently in the market.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of new clothes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Prisca

texts.fr: A. Prisca est née le 18 Janvier 1975 à Agblangandan à Sèmè-Podji,au Sud du Bénin. Prisca vit depuis vingt ans à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Prisca est mariée à OGOULOLA Félicien, un menuisier. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Prisca et Félicien vivent ensemble, mais seul Félicien assure les charges de la famille. Prisca a arrêté l'école au primaire et depuis sept ans, elle mène une activité commerciale. En effet, Prisca vend des tissus, des sacs et des chaussures qu'elle distribue à ses clients. Prisca s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomè, capitale du Togo pays voisin du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Dans le but d'agrandir son activité et de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Prisca sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Prisca envisage plus tard ouvrir sa propre boutique pour y vendre ses marchandises.
texts.en:
A. Prisca was born on January 18, 1975 in Agblangandan in Sèmè-Podji, in the south of Bénin. For twenty years, Prisca has been living in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Prisca is married to OGOULOLA Félicien, a carpenter. The couple has two children, both enrolled in school. Prisca and Félicien live together, but only Félicien supports the family.

Prisca had to stop going to school early on and for 7 years, she has been working as a merchant. In fact, Prisca sells cloth, handbags, and shoes which she distributes to her customers. She does her buying in Dantokpa, international market of Bénin, and in Lomè, the capital of Togo, a country which borders on Bénin.

Prisca is a long-time client of ALIDé's, having already received two loans that were correctly reimbursed. With a view to expanding her business and satisfying the needs of her ever-growing clientele, Prisca is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. Prisca dreams of opening her own shop later on, where she can sell her merchandise.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying 3 dozen pairs of shoes, a dozen bags, and 5 lengths of cloth

loans.name: Anleah

texts.en: Anleah is a 43-year-old single mother of one school-going child.  She lives in Runyenjes Embu, Kenya. She used funds from her first two loans to invest in her shop. Anleah sells various necessities such as dairy feeds (feed for dairy cattle), utensils, shoes, and cereals. She has since increased her daily income by 90% and managed to save a bit of her profits.  With the Kshs 90,000 that she has requested, Anleah plans to move her business to a larger space, and also to obtain more supplies (cereals and dairy feeds) that are in high demand within her community.

loans.use: Obtain more supplies to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sueba

texts.en:
Sueba is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

Sueba sells provisions, and has been in this business for over 12 years now. She has been in LAPO for over 2 years. Sueba is soliciting a loan of 70,000 to purchase more provisions to sell so she can meet the high demands of her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Roselilian

texts.en: Roselilian is a 28-year-old entrepreneur and mother of one school-age child.  She and her husband live in Runyenjes, Embu, Kenya.  She began her current business of selling second-hand clothes and plastics in 2003.  She specializes in women’s clothing: skirts, dresses, casual and formal tops.  She periodically travels to Nairobi, where she is able to purchase a good variety at wholesale prices.  The prime location of her business on a busy street, her many years of doing business and her friendly interaction with customers has enabled her to establish a good clientele base.  Her customers return to her shop for her wide selection or to make requests for certain styles.  Roselilian plans to expand her business with her next loan of Kshs 20,000.

loans.use: To expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tévi Julienne

texts.fr: A. Tévi Julienne est née vers 1971 à Tori-Bossito au Sud du Bénin. Mariée à GBENOU Pascal, un peintre, Tévi Julienne est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. En plus de ces enfants, Tévi Julienne a un enfant en charge. Le couple vit depuis dix ans à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou capitale économique du Bénin. Les charges de la famille sont supportées ensemble par Tévi Julienne et Pascal. Tévi Julienne a été à l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Depuis près de six ans, Tévi Julienne s'est livrée à la vente de maïs, de bouillie (fait à base de farine de maïs) accompagné de beignets (fait à base de farine de blé). Tévi Julienne a ajouté également à sa marchandise, la vente de farine de manioc et de galettes d'arachide. Tévi Julienne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Glazoué au Centre du Bénin. Pour renforcer son activité et réaliser plus d'économies afin d'aider son mari dans les charges familiales, Tévi Julienne sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé
texts.en:
A. Tévi Julienne was born around 1971 in Tori-Bossito in the south of Bénin. Married to GBENOU Pascal, a painter, Tévi Julienne is the mother of 2 children, both enrolled in school. Besides these children, Tévi Julienne is raising another child. The couple has been living for 10 years in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. The family's living expenses are borne by both Tévi Julienne and Pascal.

Tévi Julienne stayed in school up to high school. For almost 6 years, she has been selling maize and porridge (made with maize flour) accompanied with fritters (made with wheat flour). Tévi Julienne has also added the sale of manioc flour and peanut cookies to her business. Tévi Julienne does her buying in Dantokpa, international market of Bénin, and in Glazoué in downtown Bénin. To bolster her business and put aside more savings so as to help her husband support the family, she is requesting her first ever loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 3 sacks of wheat flour and 4 sacks of maize

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester R. is a 50-year-old mother of five children. She lives in Runyenjes Embu, Kenya. She began selling clothing door-to-door in 1983 and has since expanded her business. She used the funds from her first loan to start her own shop. She currently rents the shop where she sells clothes-making materials, shoes, purses, ties, and other clothing items.

In addition, the central location of her shop and her many years of doing good business within the community have gained her a good reputation and a wide customer base. Her business has done quite well due to the added advantage of access to loan funds; she has combined the additional money with hard work and perseverance in order to increase her stock and materials and build a successful income-generating business.

Ester is proud of her accomplishments and that she is now able to contribute to paying household expenses. Ester received a loan in the amount of Kshs 20,000 to further expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Modinat

texts.en:
Modinat is married with 5 children. She is 38 years old, and lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

Modinat sells yam flour. She has been in this business for the past 20 years. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more yam flour to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yam flour to sell

loans.name: Paula Isadora

texts.es: La señora Paula R. de 42 años de edad, reside en el barrio Edgar Munguia en la capital de Managua, procreo tres hijos de 2,14 y 16 años, los cuales estudian, trabaja como conserje y venta de comida para poder ayudar a sus hijos ya que es madre soltera y tiene que esforzarse en las venta para poder sastifacer a sus hijos, cuando inicio lo hizo con ahorros y prestamos, pero luego con prestamos en Afodenic y logro invertir en sus ventas lleva diez ciclos y se siente contenta por poder hacer las mejoras en su negocio como en su vida personal, con este préstamo invertirá en alimentos como: carnes, granos básicos, verduras y frutas para preparar los platillos y poder mantener las ventas, sus deseos  es poder apoyar a sus hijos, y puedan obtener mejores trabajos ya que es mas difícil cuando no se estudia. Da las gracias a la institución por los beneficios que ha logrado en su negocio.
texts.en:
Paula R. is 42, and she lives in the Edgar Munguia neighborhood in the capital of Managua. She has three children; 2, 14, and 16. They go to school. She works as a custodian, and she sells food to be able to help her children. She is a single mother, and she has to put forth great effort selling to be able to meet her children’s needs. She started with savings and loans. Then, with loans from Afodenic, she was able to invest in her sales. She has had ten cycles, and she feels happy to be able to make the improvements in her business and in her personal life. She will use the loan to buy food like meat, basic grains, fruit, and vegetables to make her dishes and maintain her sales. Her wishes are to be able to support her children and that they will be able to obtain better work. It is more difficult when you do not go to school She is grateful to the institution for the benefits she has attained in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meat, basic grains, fruit, and vegetables

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a 45-year-old mother of 6 children (all in school). She lives with her husband in Runyenjes Embu Kenya. She started the business of buying raw bananas for sale in 2000. She gets her stock direct from local farmers wholesale and supplies to local marketplaces,  thus she is able to make a big profit. She plans to buy more stock of raw bananas with her third loan of Kshs 30,000 and also invest part of the loan to purchase cereals like beans and dry maize, especially during this harvesting season.

loans.use: Buy more raw bananas for sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Emelina De Los Santos

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Mangua, la señora Emelina de los Santos Quintero se ha dedicado a la elaboración de alimentos y escencialmente elaboración de revueltas que son tortillas revueltas con queso siendo vendidas a diario en su negocio.

Ella se ha destacado por ser una excelente vendedora y también por preparar deliciosos alimentos. Ella ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar el crédito para la compra de la materia prima para elaborar dichos alimentos y así continuar en su actividad.
texts.en:
For a living, Mrs. Emelina de los Santos Quintero prepares food, especially "revueltas" which are tortillas mixed with cheese, which she sells on a daily basis from her business at the Mercado Mayoreo in the town of Mangua.

She has excelled as saleswoman and also as a cook of delicious dishes. She has approached Ceprodel to request a loan in order to buy ingredients for her dishes and be able to continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients to prepare food.

loans.name: Carlos Alberto

texts.es: El señor Carlos F. de 41 años de edad, es un hombre trabajador desde joven aprendió el oficio de albañil ya que su papa trabajaba en construcción y hace soldadura el cual lleva 18 años en experiencia. Casado una esposa trabajadora que le ayuda a mantener su familia ella vende tortilla, desde horas tempranas se levanta para ir al molino y moler el maíz y luego palmear  el rico alimento Nicaragüense, procreo tres hijos de 8,2 y 14 años de edad,  dos estudian su primaria lo que mas desea es poder ayudar a sus hijos para que no falten al colegio y puedan ser hombres de bien. Don Carlos lleva siete ciclos en Afodenic y con este invertirá en la compra de soldadura para hacer su trabajo. Da las gracias a la institución por dar la oportunidad de hacer las mejoras en su vida como en su negocio.
texts.en:
Mr. Carlos F. is 41 years old. He is a hard-working gentleman who learned to be a building worker when he was young as his father worked in construction. For the past 18 years he has been working as a welder. He is married, his hard-working wife helps support the family. She sells tortillas, she gets up very early to go to the mill to grind corn and then prepare the delicious Nicaraguan dish. He has three sons, age 8, 2, and 14. Two are in elementary school, and it is his wish to be able to support his children so they can stay in school and become good men. Don Carlos has had seven loans with Afodenic, and with this one he will invest in buying welding to continue his work. He is grateful to the institution for giving him the opportunity to improve his life as well as his business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase welding to continue work.

loans.name: Aida

texts.fr:
Madame Aida N.  s est pendant cinq ans spécialises  dans la vente de produits cosmétiques .Cependant selon les événements elle oriente son activité vers la demande de la clientèle.C est ce qui explique qu elle s'adonne a la vente d articles scolaires a cause de   louverture des classes. Elle habite non loin de la caisse de  Camberene  une localité qui se situe au nord de Dakar .Elle assiste beaucoup son mari dans l entretien de  ses deux enfants.par conséquent  le prêt  qu’  elle sollicite va lui permettre d augmenter son fond de roulement ce qui lui permettra d accroitre ses revenus mensuels de 10 000 frs chaque mois est le premier crédit qui lui a été  octroyé  par l U-IMCEC caisse de Camberene.
Madame Aida N.  est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF)  Seydina  Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
For five years, Ms. Aida N. has been specializing in selling cosmetics. However, according to events, she has oriented her business toward customer demands, which explains why she devotes all her time to selling school supplies, since classes have started. She lives near the office in Camberene, a town located north of Dakar. She does a lot to help her husband care for her two children. And so, the loan she’s requesting will enable her to grow her monthly revenues by 10,000 francs each month. This is the first loan allocated to her by the U-IMCEC office of Camberene. Ms. Aida N. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC and the Programme de développement de l'infant et de la famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community and especially to protect children who come from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can take advantage of loans having more flexible terms compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement’s kickoff in December 2008, there have been 120 parents who received financing in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her working capital

loans.name: Fatima Mercedes

texts.es: La joven Fátima A. de 25 años de edad, es soltera, vive en el barrio Enrique Smith en la capital de Managua, junto con sus padres el cual han apoyado para invertir en una tienda de ropa y venta de cosméticos desde hace cuatro años, el cual administra día a día para progresar y hacerlo crecer.  Ha incrementado su inventario gracias al préstamo que Afodenic financio a un plazos el cual se le hace fácil pagar en tiempo y forma, con este préstamo invertirá en compra de ropa variada, para dama, caballero y niños ya que viene la temperada buena de navidad, a si como tintes, maquillajes y otros. Sus metas como mujer es poder casarse tener sus hijos y poder agrandar su tienda ya que siempre le gusta ser independiente. Muy agradecida por el financiamiento ya que solo mediante los prestamos a plazo se puede lograr la inversión
texts.en:
Miss Fátima A. is 25 years old, single, and she lives in the neighborhood Enrique Smith of the capital of Managua with her parents who have backed her up to enable her to invest in a clothing store and cosmetics sales four years ago which she administers on a daily basis in order to get ahead and make it grow. Her inventory has increased thanks to a loan from Afodenic which she repaid punctually, and with this loan she will buy clothes for ladies, gentlemen and children as the Cristmas season is getting close, as well as dye, make-up, etc. It is her goal as a woman to get married, have children, and extend her business as she enjoys being independent. She is grateful for the loan as the only way she can invest is through loans.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase clothing for children, ladies, and gentlemen

loans.name: Maritza Elena

texts.es: Maritza Elena tiene 54 años, su actividad económica es la venta de comida. Hace más de 20 años que se dedica a este negocio, ella lucha todos los días por salir adelante con su negocio. Ella inicio ofreciendo muy pocos platillos porque no tenía el suficiente capital para ofrecerles a sus clientes una variedad de productos, pero esto no desanimo a Maritza a seguir creciendo con su negocio, por lo que más tarde decidió realizar financiamientos con el fin de mejorar en su negocio. Actualmente solicita un financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de granos básicos, gaseosas, frutas y ciertos utensilios de cocina. Su deseo es satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maritza Elena is 54 years old and for a living she has been selling food for more than 20 years. She struggles every day to get ahead with her business. She began offering very few dishes as she did not have enough capital to offer more variety to her customers, but that did not discourage Maritza from making her business grow and later she decided to use loans to improve it. Presently she is requesting a loan as work capital to buy basic grains, pops, fruit and certain kitchen appliances. It is her wish to satisfy her customers' demands.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Alba Luz

texts.es: La señora Alaba Luz  C.  de 39 años de edad, se dedica a la venta ropa y venta de fritanga desde hace 14 años el cual ha logrado mantenerlo muchas veces con ventas bajas, y se vende bastante por la temporada, reside en Villa Reconciliación junto a su esposo e hijos procreo cuatro  dos trabajan y dos estudian, su esposo es mecánico muy trabajador y buen padre, el cual la apoyado no solo en la educación si no hacer una mujer independiente, el cual he apoyado a mis hijos para que logren sus sueños de un futuro mejor. Desde horas tempranas se levanta para preparar los alimentos para la venta ya que en horas de la mañana es el movimiento de los desayunos y por las tardes esta descansa ya que es cansado al preparar los alimentos. Con este préstamo comprara alimentos para vender su rica fritanga a si como comprar zapatos y poder atrae clientes nuevos con nuevos productos es su noveno ciclo el cual agradece por el apoyo con los financiamientos que por la tasa baja de los intereses y los plazo ha logrado crecer.
texts.en:
Alba is 39 years old and for 14 years she has sold clothing and food cooked over a grill. This has maintained her, though sales have sometimes been low and seasonal. She lives in Villa Reconciliación with her husband and 4 children, 2 of whom work while 2 are students. Her husband is a hard working mechanic and a very good father. He has helped her, not only educationally but to become an independent woman, which has helped her children to achieve their dreams of a better future.

From the early hours of the morning Alba is up preparing food to sell, since breakfast is her main product. In the afternoon, she rests, weary from the labors of preparing meals all morning.

With this loan she will buy food to sell from her tasty grill and to buy shoes, in order to attract new customers with new products. This is her 9th loan cycle and she is grateful for the financial help. The low interest rate and longer repayment periods have enabled her business to grow.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY MEAT, VEGETABLES, BASIC GRAINS, AND SHOES TO SELL

loans.name: Ganiju

texts.en:
Ganiju is 56 years old and married with 9 children. He lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

Ganiju grinds things such as dried yams, garri and beans. He has been in his business for over 15 years and in LAPO for the past 2 years. Ganiyu is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase a grinding machine. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Siny

texts.fr:
Madame Siny S.  est vendeuse de légumes et de produits divers. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. A cause de l évolution de son activité  elle s active toujours de 8h a 19h le soir. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs et ambitionne de renforcer son activité. Avec ce prêt elle espère augmenter ses revenus  mensuels de 50 000 frs. Cela fait plus de dix ans que  Siny  évolue dans ce domaine.

Madame Siny S. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF)  Seydina  Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parents de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires.  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Mrs. Siny S. sells vegetables and various other products.  She is married and the mother of three children.  As a result of the growth of her business, she always works from 8 AM to 7 PM.  She is requesting a loan of FCFA 100,000 and hopes to further strengthen her business.  With this loan, she hopes to increase her monthly income by FCFA 50,000.  Siny has been active in this sector for over ten years.

Mrs. Siny S. is a beneficiary of an agreement between U-IMCEC and the Program for the Development of Children and Families (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  The PDEF works to reduce poverty within the community and protect the children of disadvantaged families.  Thanks to this partnership, the parents of the children have access to loans with more flexible conditions than regular loans.  Since the launch of the partnership in December 2008, 120 parents have received loans between FCFA 50,000 and FCFA 100,000.

loans.use: renforcer son activite

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Doña Julia de 55 años de edad, reside en el barrio Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, junto con su esposo e hijos que le ayudan a administrar su negocio un cyber que desde hace ocho años logro poner y que ha ido invirtiendo para  hacerlo mas grande y obtener mejores ganancias, cuando inicio lo hizo con prestamos en micro financieras ya que es una buena inversión pero se gasta. Desde horas tempranas se levanta y asea su casa y luego el local para dar un buen servicio a sus clientes ya que desde horas temprana llegan los estudiantes a estudiar y buscar sus investigaciones, la hora vale diez córdobas también vende productos lácteos, gaseosas y repostería para obtener mejores ingresos, y aprovecha a los jóvenes que llegan bastantes en diferentes horarios, lleva ocho ciclo en Afodenic y con este invertirá en la compra de lácteos, gaseosas y darle mantenimientos a las computadora para dar un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Miss Julia is 55 years old and lives in the neighborhood of North Laureles in the capital city of Managua. Together with her husband and children who help her she runs a cyber café. She has been running the café for 8 years and has invested in it to make it bigger and increase her earnings. She started her business with loans from micro finance institutions since the business is a good investment but costs money. She gets up early and cleans her house and surrounding area to give good service to her customers since students arrive very early to study and do research. She charges 10 córdobas an hour for internet use and she also sells dairy products, sodas, and baked goods to increase her income. She takes advantage of the fact that younger customers come on very different schedules. This is her eighth loan with Afodenic and with it she will invest in the purchase of dairy products, sodas, and will also perform maintenance on the computers to improve service.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sodas, dairy products, and perform maintenance on the computers to improve service

loans.name: Hammed

texts.en:
Hammed is 34 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Oyo state, Nigeria.

Hammed has a provisions store, which she has been operating for over 6 years. She has been with LAPO for over 2 years. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more provisions and further improve her store. Hammed say she is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Busari

texts.en:
Busari is 49 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions, jewelry, and school shoes in Oyo State, Nigeria.

Busari has been in her business for over 16 years and in LAPO for the past 2 years. Busari hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to increase the amount of provisions and shoes she has to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and shoes

loans.name: Freddy

texts.en:
Freddy C. V. is 44 years old, married with 3 children who are his first priority. They are 22, 20, and 15, respectively and all still live at home. He has a small scale farm where he grows coffee. 

The weather has been quite dry in Costa Rica this year though he is confident his crop will not suffer. He recently bought an empty lot in San Salvador, a village near San Agustin, and he would like to build a house there. His house now is not satisfactory for his 3 children and his wife, and this loan provides him the opportunity to better his family's situation. He has had one loan with FUDECOSUR in the past which he used for his coffee fields. He also had a loan with Banco Complianza but prefers FUDECOSUR's loans as they have a more manageable interest rate. 

Freddy dreams that his children will all be able to afford their own houses some day. FUDECOSUR is in their first month of partnership with Kiva and really appreciates your support of Freddy C. V..

loans.use: to purchase materials for a new house

loans.name: Ahlonkobu

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente en détail de serviettes et de draps dans le quartier de Baguida à Lomé, elle fait ce commerce de façon ambulante. Cette activité lui permet de subvenir à la plupart de ses besoins et d’apporter financièrement ses aides dans l’éducation scolaire de leurs enfants. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de hédzranawoé à Lomé mais aussi au Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes de la part de ses clients et leur réserve ses meilleurs produits à l’ouverture de nouveaux bals. Elle a approché WAGES pour pourvoir acheter de nouveaux bals ; le prêt lui permettra de commander 02 bals de draps et une bal de serviettes. Elle est confiante pour le remboursement.
texts.en:
This woman is married and is the mother of 03 children. To generate revenue, she retails napkins and sheets in the Baguida neighborhood of Lomé. She runs her business in a traveling fashion. This business allows her to meet the majority of her needs and to help financially with her childrens' schooling. She gets her supplies in the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé but also in the Grand Marché of Lomé. She receives many orders from her customers and sets aside the best products for them when she opens new bales. She has approached WAGES in order to be able to purchase new bales. This loan will allow her to order 02 bales of sheets and one bale of napkins. She is confident she will be able to reimburse this loan.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase sheets, napkins and other items

loans.name: Amparo Del Socorro
